Comment: I play this a lot - I play 1. d4 against players >1300 and 1. e4 against players <1300 as you may have seen against my previous annotations.
e3 - rather seen with stronger players that don't mind blocking their DSB.
My bishop surges into the game.
This is a really annoying move - if Bxe3 then Qxd3 and white has developed more than I had, and if my bishop moves, then I lose a tempo - white's bishop is perfect on d3.
Not much of a choice, but I choose to exchange.
He takes with the queen - the best move to avoid doubled pawns.
Knight surges into centre - I am preparing Ne4 perhaps.
Seeing this, this early queen check also forks the b-pawn.
Though this develops a piece, I actually think that c6 would have been better and if Qxb7 then Nbd7.
He greedily nabs the pawn.
Probably not that great - I try to force him back.
Looking like a deadly queen fork - even when I looked at this, first-sight, a bead of sweat came towards me, but I can wriggle.
The pawn blocks the check and the queen protects the knight - perfect!
The queen heads home.
Trying to give my DSB a path.
Developing, and targeting my knight.
I develop my bishop.
Flanky knight - as I call it. It has two other perfectly fine squares to go to, so why not go to them?
Castling from both sides.
Castling from both sides.
